_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I. Executive Summary   DRAFT
A. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
In response to the federal Environmental Protection Agency requirement, and as stipulated in Section 68 of Title 40 in the Code of Federal Regulation, and the Chemical Accident Prevention Rule under the Clean Air Act, Section 112(r); this Risk Management Plan (RMP),  has been developed for the Nunes Cooling, Inc., Yuma, AZ  produce cooling and shipping facility.  The purpose of this RMP is to:
* Increase the protection of public health and the environment by ensuring proper emergency response and mitigation procedures when handling an acutely hazardous material (AHM).
* Assist Nunes Cooling Inc. and the local government agencies in their communication and coordination efforts to improve facility safety while handling an AHM.
This document addresses the proposed AHM system for the produce refrigeration process at the Nunes Cooling, Inc. facility.  The AHM to be used at the facility and for the focus of this study is anhydrous ammonia.  The devices that use and store this AHM will be the subjects of investigation throughout this RMP document.

Nunes Cooling, Inc. is located within the city limits of Yuma, Arizona, in a predominately business/industrial area, and is a produce pre-cooling, cold storage, and shipping facility established in the 1980's and in continuous seasonal operation since that time.  Anhydrous ammonia is used as the closed loop system refrigerant for the pre-cooling and cold storage equipment and is the only acutely hazardous chemical used on the site in amounts over the reportable quantities.  The facility consists of approximately 52,500 sq. ft. of cold storage warehouse space and various types of fixed and mobile pre-cooling equipment on the approximate 9 acre site.
 
The risks to the community from this facility would come from an incident in which the ammonia normally contained within the refrigeration system was allowed to escape into the atmosphere.

The Offsite Consequence Analysis contained herein incorporates the worst-case scenario and an alternate release scenarios.   Events which were considered possible and able to cause a release of ammonia for the purposes of the Hazard Evaluation were: equipment failure, operator error, design deficiency, vehicular accident, acts of sabotage/vandalism, fire and earthquake.   It is expected that other specific events would have similar results as those listed above.   
1. Mitigation of ammonia release is addressed as follows:
A) System design and construction
B) Administrative controls
C) Operating engineer on-site daily
D) Off-hours security service
E) A release inside a building. This may involve closing the building doors.
2.  Administrative controls and policies
The Administrative controls and policies to be used in the event of a release are contained in the existing "Business Response Plan - 1999".   The major topics covered by this document are:
A) Emergency Contact List
B) Emergency Action Team
C) Notification Procedures
D) Hazardous Material Inventory
E) Site Plan, Facility Layout
F) Personnel Responsibilities
G) Evacuation Plan and Procedures
H) Employee Training
I) Employer Emergency Response Checklist
3. Risk Reduction       
Risk reduction steps have been, and are continuing to be, implemented by Nunes Cooling Inc. to minimize the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia, and in the event of an accidental release, to minimize the effects upon the community.   The essential risk reduction steps now in effect at this facility are:
A) Regular daily equipment observations
B) The weekly inspection and recording of equipment operating data
C) Maintaining equipment maintenance records
D) Maintaining records of previous releases and their causes
E) Proper training of operators
F) Mechanical and electrical system controls 
These controls automatically maintain the correct system temperatures and pressures, and provide safety shut-down and pressure relief in

the event that the system operates out of the design limits.
H) Pressure vessels are equipped with high level alarm switches.
I)  All equipment and system components are designed for ammonia service
J) System Code and Ordinance Compliance
The system was designed and installed in accordance with applicable   Federal, State and local codes and ordinances.
K) This facility currently operates under a Community Emergency Response Plan which:
1. Identifies the Emergency Coordinator and emergency contacts
2. Details the emergency notification procedures
3. Contains procedures for hazardous material incidents
4. Details Reporting procedures
5. Contains the Evacuation Plan
6. Shows the locations of all acutely hazardous materials on-site
7. Shows the locations of emergency response and mitigation equipment on-site

This facility has not experienced an ammonia release within the last five years which resulted in the evacuation and/or sheltering in place of neighboring properties.  Existing administrative controls to be used in the event of a release are contained in the "Business Response Plan".  A copy of the B.R.P. is included in the appendix.
4. Mitigation of Ammonia Releases is to be addressed by the following:
A) System Design and Construction
B) Administrative Controls
C) Equipment Testing and Maintenance Procedures
D) Ammonia Detection and Alarm System
E) Refrigeration System Control Hardware
F) Operating Engineer On-Site Daily
G) Off-Hours Security Service
H) A Release Inside the Building Could Require Closing the Building Doors
5. Recommended Plant Improvements
Recommended plant improvements to increase safety 
A) Complete the pipe labeling as per UMC and ANSI/ASHRAE standards for the cold storage facility.
B) Label main control valves on portable and fixed equipment.
C) Complete connection of all plant PRV's to diffusion tank.
D) Install Knox box at cooler office, include drawings & BRP.
E) Complete connection of ammonia detectors to automatic dialer or supervised

alarm service.
F)  Compressor piping connections are to have supports within 6' of each compressor connection.
G) The recommended date for completion of these items is March 31, 2005.
6. Utility System
The facility is connected to Arizona Public Service (APS) and is subject to possible power failures.  The failure of a refrigeration system to operate during a power outage poses no risk of an ammonia release since loss of power simply stops the flow of ammonia within the system.   In the event of a post-earthquake fire at the site, firewater is drawn from the city water system.  The post-earthquake functionality of the city's water system thus depends on the vulnerability of the system to earthquake-induced failure, which is unknown.
